title: The Triumphal Entry
subtitle: When the rejected King enters Jerusalem riding on a donkey, not a warhorse

key_verse.text: And the multitudes that went before, and that followed, cried, saying, Hosanna to the Son of David: Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord; Hosanna in the highest.

cards.title: Hosanna: A Cry of Plea Turned to Praise
cards.subtitle: The meaning behind the acclamations
cards.content:
Palm Sunday, AD 30. Jesus enters Jerusalem five days before His crucifixion. The multitudes cry 'Hosanna!' - but what does it really mean?

üì¢ THE CRY OF 'HOSANNA':

The word comes from Hebrew 'Hoshana' (◊î◊ï÷π◊©÷¥◊Å◊ô◊¢÷∏ ◊†÷∏÷º◊ê):
‚Ä¢ 'Hosha' = save
‚Ä¢ 'Na' = please, we beseech thee
‚Ä¢ Literal meaning: 'Save us now!' or 'We beseech thee, save!'

It was a cry from Psalm 118:25 sung during the Feast of Tabernacles:
'Save now, I beseech thee, O LORD: O LORD, I beseech thee, send now prosperity.'

üëë WHAT THE CROWD EXPECTED:

‚Ä¢ A POLITICAL Messiah to free them from Rome
‚Ä¢ A MILITARY king to establish David's kingdom
‚Ä¢ A leader to restore Israel's glory

They shouted 'Hosanna to the Son of David!' expecting Jesus to:
‚Ä¢ March to Pilate's palace
‚Ä¢ Expel the Romans
‚Ä¢ Sit on David's throne

üíî THE DEVASTATING IRONY:

Five days later, the SAME crowd will shout: 'Crucify him!'

Why? Because Jesus didn't meet their political expectations. He came to save, but not in the way they wanted.

His kingdom is NOT of this world (John 18:36).

greek_words.meaning: Save us now, we beseech thee to save
greek_words.revelation: The crowd was crying out for salvation, but they didn't understand WHAT kind of salvation Jesus brought. He didn't come to save them from Rome, but from sin. He didn't come to establish an earthly throne, but an eternal one.

cards.revelation_key: We often cry 'Hosanna' expecting Jesus to solve our earthly problems, but He came to solve our eternal problem: separation from God.

cards.title: The Colt: Deliberate Prophetic Fulfillment
cards.subtitle: Why Jesus chooses a donkey and not a horse
cards.content:
Jesus sends two disciples with specific instructions: 'Go into the village... ye shall find an ass tied, and a colt with her: loose them, and bring them unto me' (Matthew 21:2).

üê¥ DONKEY VS. HORSE:

In the ancient world, the animal mattered:

‚Ä¢ HORSE = symbol of WAR (conquering kings rode horses)
‚Ä¢ DONKEY/COLT = symbol of PEACE (kings entered in peace riding donkeys)

üìú PROPHETIC FULFILLMENT:

Matthew 21:4-5 directly quotes Zechariah 9:9:

'Tell ye the daughter of Sion, Behold, thy King cometh unto thee, meek, and sitting upon an ass, and a colt the foal of an ass.'

Details of fulfillment:
1. 'Thy KING cometh' ‚Üí Jesus is King
2. 'Meek' (Greek: praus) ‚Üí Humble, not proud
3. 'Upon an ass... a colt' ‚Üí Exactly as Zechariah prophesied

üéØ THE INTENTIONAL CONTRAST:

Jesus deliberately fulfills the prophecy EXACTLY:
‚Ä¢ NOT in a royal chariot
‚Ä¢ NOT on a warhorse
‚Ä¢ NOT with an army behind Him
‚Ä¢ YES on a borrowed colt, symbol of peace and humility

üí° THE MESSAGE:

Jesus is declaring:
'I am the King Zechariah prophesied, but My kingdom is not established by the sword. I come in peace, to conquer hearts, not territories.'
cards.revelation_key: The King of the universe enters riding a borrowed donkey. God's greatness is manifested in humility, not in pomp.

cards.title: Palm Branches: The Symbol of Victory and Royalty
cards.subtitle: John 12:13 - What the multitudes declared unknowingly
cards.content:
John 12:13 adds a detail that Matthew doesn't mention: 'Took branches of palm trees, and went forth to meet him.'

üå¥ PALMS IN JEWISH HISTORY:

Palm branches had profound historical significance:

1Ô∏è‚É£ FEAST OF TABERNACLES:

Leviticus 23:40 commanded taking palm branches during this feast to celebrate God's provision in the wilderness.

2Ô∏è‚É£ SYMBOL OF VICTORY:

When the Maccabees liberated Jerusalem from the Seleucid empire (164 BC), the people celebrated with palm branches (1 Maccabees 13:51).

3Ô∏è‚É£ SYMBOL OF ROYALTY:

In the ancient world, palms represented:
‚Ä¢ Military victory
‚Ä¢ Triumphant royalty
‚Ä¢ Celebration of conquest

üîó THE APOCALYPTIC CONNECTION:

Revelation 7:9 describes the heavenly scene:
'A great multitude... stood before the throne, and before the Lamb, clothed with white robes, and palms in their hands.'

The SAME palms they waved in Jerusalem appear in heaven before the Lamb's throne!

‚öîÔ∏è THE DOUBLE IRONY:

‚Ä¢ They wave palms expecting POLITICAL victory ‚Üí Jesus brings SPIRITUAL victory
‚Ä¢ They expect Him to defeat Rome ‚Üí Jesus defeats death itself
‚Ä¢ They want an EARTHLY kingdom ‚Üí Jesus establishes an ETERNAL kingdom

scripture_connections.text: Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion; shout, O daughter of Jerusalem: behold, thy King cometh unto thee: he is just, and having salvation; lowly, and riding upon an ass
Blessed be he that cometh in the name of the LORD
With palms in their hands... Salvation to our God

cards.revelation_key: The multitudes prophesied more than they understood. The palms they waved that day point to the eternal victory Christ would win on the cross.

cards.title: Jesus Weeps Over Jerusalem
cards.subtitle: Luke 19:41-44 - The rejected King laments for His city
cards.content:
In the midst of jubilation, Luke records a devastating moment the other gospels don't mention:

'And when he was come near, he beheld the city, and wept over it' (Luke 19:41).

üò≠ THE KING'S TEARS:

While the multitudes shout 'Hosanna!', Jesus WEEPS.

Why?

Because He sees what they don't see:
‚Ä¢ Within 40 years (AD 70), Jerusalem will be destroyed by Rome
‚Ä¢ The temple will be razed (Matthew 24:2)
‚Ä¢ Thousands will die because they rejected their Messiah

üíî THE WORDS OF LAMENT:

'If thou hadst known, even thou, at least in this thy day, the things which belong unto thy peace! but now they are hid from thine eyes' (Luke 19:42).

Jesus says: 'THY DAY' - the day of visitation, the day of opportunity.

But they didn't recognize it. Verse 44: 'Because thou knewest not the time of thy visitation.'

‚è∞ THE TIME OF VISITATION:

Daniel 9:25 had prophesied EXACTLY when Messiah would come:
‚Ä¢ From the decree to rebuild Jerusalem (445 BC)
‚Ä¢ Until Messiah the Prince
‚Ä¢ 69 weeks of years = 483 years

The EXACT moment was Palm Sunday!

But they didn't recognize it.

üåÜ THE TRAGEDY:

‚Ä¢ Jesus offers peace ‚Üí They choose rebellion
‚Ä¢ Jesus offers salvation ‚Üí They choose destruction
‚Ä¢ Jesus offers life ‚Üí They choose death

And Jesus, knowing all this, WEEPS.
cards.identity_statement: Jesus weeps for those who reject His salvation. His heart breaks not just for sin, but for the consequences that sin brings.
cards.revelation_key: The day of visitation comes, but it doesn't last forever. There is a time to recognize the King, and rejecting Him has eternal consequences.

discovery_questions.question: The multitudes wanted Jesus to be a political king. In what areas of your life have you tried to make Jesus fit YOUR expectations instead of surrendering to His plan?
The crowd shouted 'Hosanna!' on Sunday and 'Crucify him!' on Friday. What does this reveal about worship based on emotions vs. worship based on genuine commitment?
Jesus wept because Jerusalem didn't recognize 'the time of thy visitation.' Are there areas of your life where God is visiting you and you haven't recognized it?

prayer.title: Prayer of the Humble King
prayer.content: Jesus, King of kings who enters riding on a donkey. Forgive me for the times I've shouted 'Hosanna' expecting You to fulfill MY plans, instead of surrendering to Yours. Thank You that You didn't come as an earthly conquering king, but as the King who conquers hearts. Help me recognize the time of Your visitation in my life. May my worship not depend on You meeting my expectations, but on who You are. Today I receive You as my King, not the king I want, but the King You are. In Jesus' name, Amen.
